Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: An Multi-technique Approach to Dietary Reconstruction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this doctoral dissertation research project MS Susan Kooiman, of Michigan State University, will investigate the role of food and cooking in past human social and environmental interactions. Food choice and preparation methods are conscious and unconscious expressions of human identity, offering a window into who people are and how they wish to be perceived. Archaeological exploration of past foodways offers insight into how diet and cooking are connected to environmental, social, technological, political, and ideological factors, highlighting the dynamism and diversity of human adaptive and cultural decisions about food that are often not visible within the modern industrial system. Transformation of diet and cooking techniques through time are often reflections of broader environmental and sociocultural changes. Cooking technology, such as pottery, is also sensitive to social change, altering in form to accommodate food processing requirements and in design to reflect symbolic identity. The use of a variety of analytic techniques for investigating diet, food processing technology, and cooking methods is an innovative way to explore these issues, the effectiveness of which could help researchers across the world investigate the role of food in human negotiations with their natural and social environments. It can also inform reconstruction of traditional foodways for groups such as Native Americans, demonstrating the depth of their culinary traditions and aiding in recent traditional foodways revitalization initiatives.

MS Kooiman will investigate technological adaptations and foodways through an examination of pottery and microscopic and chemical analysis of food remains. Researchers have previously noted shifts in food choice, technology, settlement patterns, and social organization in the Woodland and Contact periods (200 B.C. - A.D. 1600) in the northern Great Lakes of North America. Some of these are hypothesized to be the result of an increasing focus on a more limited range of food resources. This process will be explored through analysis of ceramic cooking vessels spanning this period from the Cloudman site (20CH6), located on Drummond Island in Lake Huron. A set of diverse yet complementary analytic methods will be employed. Functional and typological pottery analyses will reveal potential alterations in pottery style, construction, and use over time, and a variety of specialized analyses for investigating diet (lipid residue, microbotanical, and stable isotope analyses) will confirm or refute associations between changes in pottery form and use, shifting diet, and changing social relationships. The results will demonstrate the efficacy of multidimensional ceramic and paleodietary research for use in archaeological contexts across the globe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Food is a central part of everyday life, as well as an essential component of special occasions, holidays, and ceremonies. Cuisine, which includes both the types of foods people eat and the ways in which these foods are cooked and prepared, is often associated with group and/or individual identity (including ethnicity, gender, economic class, religion, etc.). Archaeological investigations of ancient cuisine provide clues about the various and complex factors that shape and influence the development of distinctive cuisine and the specialized technologies used to prepare and cook food.

              Traditional archaeological methods used to investigate diet and cuisine focus on visible remains of animals (bones) and plants (seeds),aka macro-remains,  but these materials do not always preserve well in certain regions broadly or specific archaeological sites. Archaeological science has developed and refined new methods of investigating diet using microscopic and chemical food remains associated with food processing tools. Throughout much of North America, ceramic cooking pots were unsealed and porous, allowing food residues to both absorb into the vessel wall, and to burn and adhere to the interior surfaces of the vessels. Lipid residue analysis of absorbed residues absorbed into the vessel walls identifies fatty acids associated with broad categories of plants and animals, and stable isotope analysis uses variants of carbon and nitrogen to distinguish between tropical and temperate plants and between terrestrial and aquatic foods. Identification of microscopic plant remains (such as pollen, phytoliths, and starches) can provide species-level identification of plant foods not necessarily represented by seeds. Each method contributes unique and complementary information about the components of food residues, and together these methods can provide a holistic picture of past cuisine can be reconstructed.

              This methodology was used to investigate diet and cuisine in the northern Great Lakes of the North America, where preservation of plant and animal remains is generally poor due to drainage and soil chemistry. Archaeologists have long observed changes in settlement locations and food resource selection of Indigenous groups occupying this region during the Middle Woodland (200 BC ? AD 600) and Late Woodland (AD 500/600 ? AD 1600 or European contact) periods, but there has been much debate about the nature of this change. The Cloudman site, located in the eastern Upper Peninsula on Drummond Island in Lake Huron, was periodically occupied by local Indigenous groups from AD 100 into the 17th century fur trade era. This site contained pottery dating from AD 100 to AD 1500, and was therefore ideal for investigating changing culinary traditions.

              This project demonstrated that cooking methods at the Cloudman site shifted between the Middle and Late Woodland periods. Middle Woodland cooks showed a preference for stewing foods, while Late Woodland occupants of the Cloudman site boiled food more frequently than their predecessors. However, there appear to be no major shift in the types of foods being cooked during this time, although there may be relationship between these cooking methods and altering methods for preparing maize (corn). A decrease in maize consumption and an increase in wild rice consumption appears to have occurred after AD 1200. This could be related to changes in climate and vegetation associated with the Medieval Warm Period, demonstrating the impact that even subtle climatic and environmental change can have on diet and cuisine. 

The results of this project helped resolve a long-standing archaeological question concerning the nature of dietary change in the northern Great Lakes during the Woodland period. It supports prior findings that wild rice became increasingly important in local cuisine during the late Late Woodland period and indicates that previously hypothesized increased reliance on maize at coastal sites during the same period of time did not occur at the Cloudman site. Nuts and aquatic resources were important throughout the entire occupational history of the Cloudman site. These conclusions were only possible through the combined use of multiple advanced methods of dietary analysis applied to archaeological pottery residues and demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach for investigating ancient cuisine.
